article_title: How All Financial Markets Turned Into the Same Big Trade
article_text: LISTEN TO ARTICLE    :56      SHARE THIS ARTICLE   Share   Tweet   Post   Email  {"contentId":"QHCZKHT0AFB401","position":"brokerboxarticle","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[120,60]],"small_desktop":[[120,60]],"tablet":[[120,60]]},"strategy":"viewable","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"brokerboxarticle1","url":"/news/articles/2020-09-28/how-all-financial-markets-turned-into-the-same-big-trade"},"containerId":"brokerboxarticle-z2IEPDu"}      Photographer: da-kuk/Getty Images    Photographer: da-kuk/Getty Images   Subscribe to Odd Lots (Spotify)  Subscribe to Odd Lots (Apple Podcasts)    Every week, hosts Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway take you on a not-so-random walk through hot topics in markets, finance, and economics.         These days it seems like all financial markets are the same big trade. A gold chart looks like a Tesla chart, which looks like an Ethereum chart, which looks like a chart of a basket of cloud computing stocks. So why is this? And what could cause that to change? On this episode, we speak with Jared Woodard, the head of the Research Investment Committee at Bank of America, who recently published a report on exactly this. As Woodard explains it, the question starts with low growth and inequality, and the premium that investors will pay for certain types of securities in such an environment. He walked us through how that might change, and what investors can do in the meantime to discover under-appreciated values in the market.
